prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI in NGC253
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic of the CI emission in NGC253 to cover its central 58"x30". Central coordinates taken from Sakamoto et al. 2011.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Bright [CI] emission has been detected along the disk in NGC253 by Israel et al. (1995) with peak fluxes ranging between 0.5-2K in 10" large SD beams (Fig1) along the central disk. Assuming a conversion factor of 50Jy/K (JCMT), a requested angular resolution of 0.35" (C36-3, see also next Section) and a very conservative uniform distribution within 8", we expect a [CI] emission of at least 50mJy per beam. Based on the ALMA time estimator, we will need ~50s per pointing or ~46minutes on-source in total to reach an rms noise level of 10mJy at a spectral resolution of 15km/s which will be necessary to analyse the kinematics in this source at high signal-to-noise ratio (>=5sigma) and resolve kinematics of the GMCs (expected line width ~90km/s). In total, including overheads and time for calibration, the requested observing time amounts to ~1.6h for the 12m-array. We will need an extra ~3.2h of total observing time with ACA to recover the extended emission. In total, ~4.8h are needed to match the science goals for this source which is a bit larger than requested last cycle due to the increased angular resolution and hence deeper noise levels needed.
Finally, we want to note that as a free bonus we will also be able to obtain maps of the SiO, CS and Methanol emission. However, these lines have not been taken into account to derive the required sensitivities and observing times and are not regarded as crucial to reach our science goals.

To obtain good SNRs even for the weakest peaks along the disk, we ask for a velocity resolution of 15km/s which should sample well the line widths of the individual GMCs of (FWHM=~90km/s; see also Leroy et al. 2015). We still chose a spectral setting of 2.4km/s (for an averaging factor of 8) to allow for a more in detail analysis of the stronger peaks/GMCs which significantly helps to keep the data rates at reasonable levels.

We want to map the CI(3P1-3P0) emission in the central disk in NGC253 which has been detected at high angular resolution (0.3-1") in several CO transitions. To cover the entire SB dominated disk and the superbubbles seen at both edges of the disk (Sakamoto et al. 2011, Bolatto et al. 2013, Krips et al., 2015), we will need 57 pointings in Nuyquist sampling to match the central 58"x30". Given that we expect extended emission larger than 5" in the channel maps, we will additionally need ACA time; TP is not required this time as we do not expect the emission to be larger than 10".
NGC235 is visible during an LST range of 21h to 05h, assuming elevations of at least 40deg which are better suited for these high frequency observations. Taking also into account weather conditions (Fig.1 from the ALMA Cycle3 Proposer's Guide), observations are possible starting in April 2016 with configuration C36-3, i.e., when NGC253 is visible for at least 2h during the night time LST ranges recommended by ALMA which is enough to schedule the proposed observations. C36-3 offers an angular resolution around 0.3" (0.4") in robust (natural) weighting which is well suited for the proposed observations and hence better than proposed previously in Cycle-2. However, should the observations be still carried out in Cycle-2, we do not ask to repeat these observations in Cycle-3.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI in NGC1068
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CI observations of NGC1068 at high angular resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Bright CI emission has been detected in the center of NGC1068 by Israel (2009) with peak fluxes of Ta*=250mK in 10" large SD beams (Fig1; Tmb=500mK, Ta*=0.5*Tmb). Assuming a conversion factor between S(Jy) and Ta* of 50Jy/K (JCMT), the requested angular resolution of 0.2" (=22pc) and a conservative uniform distribution within the central 5" (spectrally resolved it is probably closer to 2-3"), we expect a CI emission of at least 20mJy per beam. Based on the ALMA time estimator, we will need ~40minutes of on-source time to reach an rms noise level of 4mJy at a spectral resolution of 10km/s which will be necessary to analyse the kinematics in this source at high signal-to-noise ratios (>5sigma). In total, including overheads and time for calibration, the requested observing time amounts to ~1.3h for the 12m-array.
As opposed to NGC253 and Arp220, we won't be able to simultaneously observe SiO and CS in NGC1068 because these lines are shifted to unfavorable frequencies with poor atmospheric transmission. However, some weaker lines might be detectable for NGC1068 (e.g., C34S) but these are seen as a free bonus if detected but are not necessary to reach the science goals of this proposal.

To spectrally resolve the emission in the different components seen in previous CO observations (>50km/s), we need at least 10km/s spectral resolution. However, to keep the option of going higher in spectral resolution for the strongest emission, we ask for an initial resolution of 2-2.5km/s which represents an averaging factor of 8 and hence a signficant reduction of data rates.

We want to map the CI(3P1-3P0) emission in the central 4" in NGC1068 which has been already mapped at high angular resolution (0.2"-0.5") in several CO transitions (Fig.2). To cover the circumnuclear disk which is dominated by the AGN, one pointing with the field of view of 12" in band8 will be largely sufficient.
NGC1068 is visible in the LST range of 23h to 06h above elevations of 40deg, being more realistic for band8. Considering constraints from weather as well (Fig.1 from the ALMA Cycle3 Proposer's Guide), observations will be possible starting in May 2016 when NGC1068 is visible for at least 1-2h in the recommended night LST ranges for ALMA which is enough to schedule the proposed observations. As a compromise between angular resolution and recoverable larger scale structures, we ask for the C36-4 configuration matching well the required 0.2" above (for a more natural weighting). Similar to NGC253 and although we ask for a higher angular resolution in Cycle-3 compared to Cycle-2 (0.2" instead of 0.3"), we do not request to repeat the Cycle-2 observations in Cycle-3 should they have been carried out in the meantime.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI in ARP220
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CI observations of Arp220 at high angular resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Bright CI emission has been detected in the center of Arp220 by Papadopoulos & Greve (2004) with peak fluxes of ~60mK in 10" large SD beams (Fig1). Assuming a conversion factor of 50Jy/K (JCMT), the requested angular resolution of 0.2" (=90pc) and a conservative uniform distribution in the central ~3", we expect a [CI] line peak fluxes of at least ~15mJy per beam. Based on the ALMA time estimator, we will need ~40minutes of on-source time to reach an rms noise level of 3mJy at a spectral resolution of 15km/s which will be necessary to analyse the kinematics in this source at high signal-to-noise ratio (>=5sigma). In total, including overheads and time for calibration, the requested observing time amounts to ~1.4h for the 12m-array.
Similar to NGC253, we expect to be able to detect also SiO and CS emission as a free bonus in Arp220. However, this is seen as an asset but not as crucial for the science goals of this proposal.

To spectrally resolve the emission well in the different components seen in previous CO observations, we need at least a spectral resolution of 15km/s. However, to keep the option of going higher in spectral resolution for the strongest emission, we ask for an initial resolution of ~2km/s which represents an averaging factor of 8 and hence still a signficant reduction of data rates.

We want to map the CI(3P1-3P0) emission in the central 3" of Arp220 which has been already mapped at high angular resolution (<=0.5") in several CO transitions (Fig.2). To cover the circumnuclear disk which is dominated by the AGN, one pointing with the field of view of 12" in band8 will be sufficient.
Arp220 is visible above an elevation of 40deg in the LST range of 14h-17h making it an excellent candidate for CI observations for Cycle3 as this corresponds to the recommended LST night range, starting in March until September 2016. To best match the science goal and as a best compromise between angular resolution and required sensitivity, we ask for the C36-4 configuration for which good weather conditions can be expected in May 2016. We do not ask to repeat the observations in Cycle3 should Arp220 be observed until then.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Exploiting the unique ALMA capabilities of band8, we propose to map for the first time the [CI] emission in three nearby prototypical galaxies, the starburst galaxy NGC253, the Seyfert galaxy NGC1068 and the ULIRG and merger Arp220, at unprecedented subarcsecond angular resolution and sensitivity. We aim to evaluate the promising potential of [CI] emission as alternative to CO to trace the interstellar medium in active galaxies. How similar is the [CI] emission to that of CO in these sources? Can it trace CO-dark and hence yet mostly unexplored regions? Are there differences in the [CI] properties between different activity types (NGC1068 vs. NGC253) and different star formation efficiencies (NGC253 vs. Arp220)? What are the effects of shocks onto [CI]? The proposed observations will further allow us to build up templates for the high-z galaxy population for which [CI] observations are booming thanks to recent improvements of millimeter interferometers.
This is a resubmission of a B-ranked (top 10%) Cycle2 proposal (2013.1.00368) that has been set ready for observations but has not yet been started (as of the deadline). We hence ask to observe the non-executed scheduling blocks.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00368.S, Atomic carbon in nearby active galaxies: Studying [CI] in NGC253, NGC1068 and Arp220, Melanie Krips
